column9: Initiative from the undisclosed GRI (found by the coder but not mentioned in the GRI index table)

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: The Framework guides our efforts to create a more consistent approach to increasing diversity of thought and experience across our business. The Framework encompasses and builds upon our efforts to date, much of which has focused on female participation, given the low gender diversity in our industry.
column20: Diversity and Inclusion Framework, Strategy, policy

column6: Ratio of basic salary and remuneration of women to men
column7: Not reported. Further details on gender equality are available in our annual report to the Australian Workplace Gender Equality Agency.

column6: Incidents of discrimination and corrective actions taken

column4: Freedom of Association and Collective Bargaining
column6: Operations and suppliers in which the right to freedom of association and collective bargaining may be at risk
column7: Under Australia's industrial relations framework, enterprise agreements (EAs) are negotiated collectively with employees and their bargaining and union representatives. New EAs are usually negotiated every three or four years, and final contracts are approved by and registered with the Fair Work Commission and made publicly available.

column6: Operations and suppliers at significant risk for incidents of child labor
column7: Risk analysis undertaken for the Group indicates that the risk of slavery-like practices in the first tier of our supply chain is shallow. Some items used in the Group's operations are routinely imported from outside Australia. The risks of slavery-like practices, while low in the immediate supply chain interface, may exist in layers further up the supply chain.

column6: Operations and suppliers ar significant risk for incidents of forced or compulsory labor
column7: Our procurement contracts include specific assurances and other undertakings from suppliers concerning modern slavery and labour practices. These include representations that all relevant legal requirements and awards will engage employees and that neither the supplier nor its immediate suppliers have committed illegal slavery-like offences. Additionally, prospective suppliers must provide information about their modern slavery-related policies and procedures as part of the onboarding process.

Incidents of violations involving rights of indigenous peoples

Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Bengalla's Community Consultative Committee (CCC) comprises a range of community representatives, including representatives from Muswellbrook Shire Council. CCC members and meeting minutes are available on our website.

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: New Acland's Community Reference Group is an advisory body comprising residents representing different parts of the community, including health, education, landholders and local Government.

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: This year, we have further enhanced our community engagement by appointing additional team members at New Acland and increased coordination to share approaches across the Group. We engage directly with local landholders on an ongoing basis on matters including land access, environmental monitoring, road closures, and operational updates. We also manage agricultural operations near our mine sites to minimise local impacts and ensure productive land use.

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column8: New Acland Mine Community Information Centre
column13: The Centre was a mainstay of Campbell Street but closed when New Acland was placed into care and maintenance in March 2021. It is now open five days a week and is a one-stop shop for locals eager to discuss job and sponsorship opportunities, ask questions or raise concerns related to New Acland.

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: We contribute to and invest in a range of community groups and initiatives, focusing on skills, training and employability, as well as broader social and community development. At Bengalla, community groups have multiple formal pathways to seek financial and in-kind support, all focused on the immediate local community.
column20: Community groups, skills training, employability, social development

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column8: Partnering with PCYC to Build Resilience
column13: We recognise community-based organisations' work to support resilience and inclusion amongst young people and are proud to partner with Police Citizens Youth Clubs (PCYC) near our mine sites. Last year, we kicked off a two-year partnership with PCYC Toowoomba's Youth Connect program, investing $360,000 to enable the team to employ two youth workers and fund their program to support young people's social, physical and mental well-being needs.
column20: Partnership with Police Citizens Youth Clubs (PCYC), Movement, Engagement

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: We have respectful relationships with local First Nations community members around our operations. We do not have Native Title or Indigenous Land Use Agreements associated with our mining or agricultural operations or our Queensland Bulk Handling facility, as registered native title claims do not cover these areas.

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: At Bengalla, we work with the Wanaruah Local Aboriginal Land Council (LALC), and a representative from the LALC is a member of the Bengalla CCC. We manage Aboriginal cultural heritage using the approved Aboriginal Cultural Heritage Management Plan. We periodically undertake cultural heritage surveys to ensure accurate information when undertaking ground disturbance activities.
column20: Aboriginal Cultural Heritage Management Plan, Wanaruah LALC

column6: Operations with significant actual and potential negative impacts on local communities
column7: We work to ensure local community access to decision-making processes, grievance mechanisms, and other remediation processes to facilitate meaningful engagement and seek to understand and address any actual or potential adverse impacts from our activities. Community members can learn about our operated sites, share feedback, ask questions, and raise concerns through various formal and informal channels.

Political contributions
column7: The New Hope Board must approve any political donations. No political contributions were made during the year. When donations are made, they are disclosed in line with applicable state and federal requirements.
